Bakat cilik hasil tanjak [METROTV]
05 Nov 2019, 20:53 by Redzuan Muharam



BUKAN hanya gemar memakai tanjak malah Muhammad Haziem Hisham yang berusia sembilan tahun berbakat menghasilkan aksesori warisan tradisional itu.
Kebolehan Muhammad Haziem mendapat perhatian warganet selepas videonya menyempurnakan ikatan tanjak tular di laman sosial.
Video berkenaan dimuat naik sepupunya, Muhammad Khairi Khairul Anuar, 23, dan meraih 157,000 tontonan sehingga kini dengan rata-rata warganet memuji kebolehan Muhammad Haziem yang mahir menghasilkan tanjak pada usia muda.
Muhammad Haziem yang juga murid Sekolah Kebangsaan (SK) Cochrane berkata, dia minat menghasilkan tanjak sejak melihat ada individu memakainya ketika menghadiri majlis perkahwinan.
Katanya, sejak itu dia cuba mempelajari teknik ikatan yang betul dan kini mahir menghasilkan dua jenis tanjak yang dinamakan ‘NakhodaTerung’ dan ‘Dendam Tak Sudah’.
“Saya belajar sendiri di Youtube dan sekarang boleh menyiapkan ikatan tanjak dalam tempoh tidak sampai dua minit.
“Ada rakan tidak pernah tengok, tanya apa itu tanjak dan ada juga yang mahu belajar daripada saya cara menghasilkannya.
“Saya tidak malu kerana memang suka pakai tanjak, kadang-kadang dengan baju Melayu atau baju T,” katanya ketika ditemui di rumahnya di Projek Perumahan Rakyat (PPR) Seri Alam, Kuala Lumpur hari ini.


Muhammad Haziem menunjukkan cara membuat lipatan tanjak. FOTO Rosela Ismail

Sementara itu, ibunya, Rosida Ishak, 49, berkata, dia dan suami Hisham Ghazali, 51, tidak pernah mengajar teknik ikatan tanjak sebaliknya Muhammad Haziem mempelajarinya sendiri dengan menonton video tutorial di Youtube.
“Dia minat terhadap tanjak selepas menghadiri majlis kenduri kahwin serta melihat sekumpulan penunggang motosikal memakainya.
“Minatnya bertambah selepas menonton filem Upin Ipin : Keris Siamang Tunggal dan sejak itu, dia sering bertanya mengenai tanjak kerana mengatakan ia unik.
“Mulanya dia cuba membuat ikatan tanjak dengan kertas jenis A4 saja dan serius dengan hobinya itu selepas terjumpa kain samping ayahnya.
“Setiap malam dia menonton Youtube seterusnya mempelajari sendiri cara ikatan tanjak dan kini, Haziem (Muhammad Haziem) gemar memakainya ke mana saja termasuk ketika pulang ke kampung, pergi mengaji, solat, berjalan atau bermain,” katanya.


Antara tanjak yang dihasilkan. FOTO Rosela Ismail

Dalam pada itu Hisham bercadang mengasah kemahiran anaknya itu dengan menghantarnya menyertai kursus kemahiran.
“Tak sangka minat dia sampai ke tahap ini dan terkejut juga selepas dapat tahu kisahnya tular di laman sosial.
“Melihat kesungguhannya, saya dan isteri bercadang menghantarnya ke kelas kemahiran supaya dia mendapat sijil.
“Sekurang-kurangnya, dia boleh berkongsi kemahiran itu dengan orang lain dan buat masa ini, ada juga rakannya datang ke rumah untuk belajar cara ikatan tanjak,” katanya.


Muhammad Haziem bersama tanjak yang dihasilkannya. FOTO Rosela Ismail

Little talent on the pitch [METROTV]
05 Nov 2019, 20:53 by Redzuan Muharam



Not only is he fond of wearing heels, but nine-year-old Muhammad Haziem Hisham has the talent to produce such traditional accessories.
Muhammad Haziem's ability to gain public attention after his video completes the social networking posts.
The video was uploaded by his cousin, Muhammad Khairi Khairul Anuar, 23, and has garnered 157,000 views to date with the average citizen praising Muhammad Haziem's ability to master youth.
Muhammad Haziem, who is also a student of Cochrane National School (SK), said he had been interested in producing skirts since he had seen people wear them while attending weddings.
He said he has since learned the proper technique of bonding and is now skilled in producing two types of skulls called 'MasterHeader' and 'Undecided.'
“I learned it on Youtube myself and can now complete the rope bond in less than two minutes.
"Some friends have never looked, asked what their strengths are and others want to learn from me how to make them.
"I'm not ashamed because it is like to wear headgear, sometimes with Malay dress or T-shirt," he said when met at his home in People's Housing Project (PPR) Seri Alam, Kuala Lumpur today.


Muhammad Haziem shows how to make a skirt fold. PHOTOS Rosela Ismail

Meanwhile, her mother, Rosida Ishak, 49, said she and husband Hisham Ghazali, 51, had never taught rope bonding techniques but Muhammad Haziem learned it himself by watching tutorial videos on Youtube.
"He was interested in the stakes after attending a wedding and seeing a group of motorcyclists wearing them.
“His interest increased after watching the movie Upin Namp: Si Si Si Single Sing and since then, he has often asked about the scenery for saying it is unique.
“He initially tried to make a rope tie with only A4 paper and was serious about the hobby after finding his father's cloth.
"Every night he watches Youtube and learns himself how to knit rope and now, Haziem (Muhammad Haziem) likes to wear it everywhere including coming home, studying, praying, walking or playing," he said.


Among the strengths generated. PHOTOS Rosela Ismail

In the meantime, Hisham plans to hone his son's skills by sending him to skills courses.
“I didn't expect her to get to this point and was shocked to find out that her story had spread on social sites.
“Seeing her earnestness, my wife and I decided to send her to the skills class to get her a certificate.
"At least he can share those skills with others and at the moment, some of his friends are coming home to learn how to knit," he said.
